abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Local Government Support
            Project (LGSP) for Tanzania were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: key operational lessons from LGSP
            were incorporated into the design of the new Program for
            results (PforR) urban local government strengthening
            program. These include: (i.) distinguishing between urban
            and rural local governments due to the different financial
            and capacity needs, (ii.) using independent assessors to
            increase transparency, (iii.) providing a financial
            incentive for central government to disburse funds on time,
            and (iv.) adopting the same collaborative and comprehensive
            preparation practices. The project adopted a low-risk
            approach for upgrading with minimal trunk infrastructure and
            resettlement. The impact evaluation shows improved access to
            services, health and education benefits. Future initiatives
            have room to be more ambitious and to try to improve
            coverage and connectivity to trunk infrastructure. Thinking
            beyond infrastructure and looking at human development
            factors is the key to successful upgrading. Counterpart
            contributions were required at all levels for all
            components- the rationale at project design was to
            demonstrate demand and commitment. However, it is not clear
            that counterpart contributions increased ownership. As the
            counterpart contributions (5 percent of capital costs)
            required from poor communities had no direct link with
            Operations and Maintenance (O and M) requirements for the
            investments, this raises questions regarding appropriateness
            of arrangements for the collection and use of funds.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Local Government Support Program
            Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement policy framework (RPF)
            provides the guidelines to minimize the negative impacts of
            land acquisition, and involuntary resettlement resulting
            from implementation of the Local Government Support Program
            Project. Resettlement and compensation will be executed as
            sustainable development programs, providing investment
            resources to give displaced persons the opportunity to share
            project benefits. Community compensation will be in-kind
            only, in the form of reconstruction of facilities, such as
            school building (public or religious), public toilets, well
            or pump, market place, road, and/or storage warehouse.
            Compensation for loss of land will be at replacement costs
            for equal productive value, or in cash estimated at market
            values in the local currency adjusted to inflation; however,
            in-kind compensation may also include items such as land,
            houses, building materials, seedlings, agricultural inputs,
            and financial credits for equipment. Crop losses will be
            compensated based on: cash crops, determined at the average
            value over the previous year, corrected for inflation;
            subsistence crops will be determined at the highest value
            over the previous year, corrected for inflation. The value
            of stable crops will be determined at the highest market
            price reached during the year. Given the significance of
            horticultural, floricultural and fruit trees - particularly
            mangoes and coconut - to the local subsistence economy,
            compensation will be on a combined replacement/market value
            form. Other domestic cash crops, and fruit trees, considered
            "wild" trees, will be compensated under the
            umbrella of the village, or community compensation. Examples
            are: avocado, bananas, guava, citrus fruits, papaya,
            tamarind, etc.

12086617.trustfund:
TF026417-PHRD-TANZANIA: LOCAL GOVERNMENT
            AND COMMUNITY UPGRADING PROJECT,TF030371-DANISH CTF FY03 - SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04,TF039820-MOZAMBIQUE - MUNICIPAL

repnme.cdata!: Tanzania - Local Government Support Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Local Government
            Support Program Project in Tanzania is to: (a) strengthen
            fiscal decentralization, and improve accountability in the
            use of local government resources and in the management of
            intergovernmental transfer systems; and (b) increase access
            to infrastructure and services in the unplanned areas of Dar
            es Salaam and improve revenue performance for sustainable
            operations and maintenance. The restructuring involves the
            reallocation of significant cost savings in component one
            and a large part of the unallocated funds to finance: (a)
            cost increases of US$4.1 million in phase one of the
            Community Infrastructure Upgrading Project (CIUP) supported
            under component two; (b) an allocation of US$20.8 million
            for phase two of CIUP; and (c) an allocation of US$7.5
            million for preparation activities for the Tanzania
            Strategic Cities Project (TSCP). The changes also include
            refinements to the results framework, removal of the
            household sanitation activities, and a one-year extension in
            the project's closing date. Since the changes involve
            modifications to the project development objectives and
            associated outcome targets.
